title: Complex numbers and the cmath module
The
cmath
c
module is similar to the
math
c
module, but defines functions appropriately for the complex plane.

inline_content.Text: module, but defines functions appropriately for the complex plane.

title: First of all, complex numbers are a numeric type that is part of the Python language itself rather than being provided by a library class. Thus we don’t need to
import cmath
c
for ordinary arithmetic expressions.

inline_content.Text: First of all, complex numbers are a numeric type that is part of the Python language itself rather than being provided by a library class. Thus we don’t need to

title: We must use
1j
c
since
j
c
would be the name of a variable rather than a numeric literal.

inline_content.Text: would be the name of a variable rather than a numeric literal.

title: We have the
real
c
part and the
imag
c
(imaginary) part, as well as the complex
conjugate
c

inline_content.Text: (imaginary) part, as well as the complex

title:
# real part and imaginary part are both float type
z.real, z.imag
# Out: (1.0, 3.0)

z.conjugate()
# Out: (1-3j)    # z.conjugate() == z.real - z.imag * 1j

content_resolved.code:
# real part and imaginary part are both float type
z.real, z.imag
# Out: (1.0, 3.0)

z.conjugate()
# Out: (1-3j)    # z.conjugate() == z.real - z.imag * 1j

title: The built-in functions
abs
c
and
complex
c
are also part of the language itself and don’t require any import:

inline_content.Text: are also part of the language itself and don’t require any import:

title:
abs(1 + 1j)
# Out: 1.4142135623730951     # square root of 2

complex(1)
# Out: (1+0j)

complex(imag=1)
# Out: (1j)

complex(1, 1)
# Out: (1+1j)

content_resolved.code:
abs(1 + 1j)
# Out: 1.4142135623730951     # square root of 2

complex(1)
# Out: (1+0j)

complex(imag=1)
# Out: (1j)

complex(1, 1)
# Out: (1+1j)

title: The
complex
c
function can take a string, but it can’t have spaces:

inline_content.Text: function can take a string, but it can’t have spaces:

title:
complex('1+1j')
# Out: (1+1j)

complex('1 + 1j')
# Exception: ValueError: complex() arg is a malformed string

content_resolved.code:
complex('1+1j')
# Out: (1+1j)

complex('1 + 1j')
# Exception: ValueError: complex() arg is a malformed string

title: Naturally the behavior of
sqrt
c
is different for complex numbers and real numbers. In non-complex
math
c
the square root of a negative number raises an exception:

inline_content.Text: is different for complex numbers and real numbers. In non-complex
the square root of a negative number raises an exception:

title:
import math

math.sqrt(-1)
# Exception: ValueError: math domain error

content_resolved.code:
import math

math.sqrt(-1)
# Exception: ValueError: math domain error

title: Functions are provided to convert to and from polar coordinates:

inline_content.Text: Functions are provided to convert to and from polar coordinates:

title: The mathematical field of complex analysis is beyond the scope of this example, but many functions in the complex plane have a “branch cut”, usually along the real axis or the imaginary axis. Most modern platforms support “signed zero” as specified in IEEE 754, which provides continuity of those functions on both sides of the branch cut. The following example is from the Python documentation:

inline_content.Text: The mathematical field of complex analysis is beyond the scope of this example, but many functions in the complex plane have a “branch cut”, usually along the real axis or the imaginary axis. Most modern platforms support “signed zero” as specified in IEEE 754, which provides continuity of those functions on both sides of the branch cut. title:
cmath.log(1+1j)
# Out: (0.34657359027997264+0.7853981633974483j)

cmath.exp(1j * cmath.pi)
# Out: (-1+1.2246467991473532e-16j)   # e to the i pi == -1, within rounding error

content_resolved.code:
cmath.log(1+1j)
# Out: (0.34657359027997264+0.7853981633974483j)

cmath.exp(1j * cmath.pi)
# Out: (-1+1.2246467991473532e-16j)   # e to the i pi == -1, within rounding error

title: The
cmath
c
module also provides complex versions of
isinf
c
, and (for Python 3.2+)
isfinite
c
. See “
Infinity and NaN
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/python/230/math-module/3973/infinity-and-nan-not-a-number
”. A complex number is considered infinite if either its real part or its imaginary part is infinite.

inline_content.Text: module also provides complex versions of
”. A complex number is considered infinite if either its real part or its imaginary part is infinite.

title: Likewise, the
cmath
c
module provides a complex version of
isnan
c
. See “
Infinity and NaN
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/python/230/math-module/3973/infinity-and-nan-not-a-number
”. A complex number is considered “not a number” if either its real part or its imaginary part is “not a number”.

inline_content.Text: module provides a complex version of
”. A complex number is considered “not a number” if either its real part or its imaginary part is “not a number”.

title:
cmath.isinf(complex(0.0, math.inf))
# Out: True

cmath.isnan(complex(math.nan, 0.0))
# Out: True

cmath.inf
# Exception: AttributeError: module 'cmath' has no attribute 'inf'

content_resolved.code:
cmath.isinf(complex(0.0, math.inf))
# Out: True

cmath.isnan(complex(math.nan, 0.0))
# Out: True

cmath.inf
# Exception: AttributeError: module 'cmath' has no attribute 'inf'

title: In Python 3.5 and higher, there is an
isclose
c
method in both
cmath
c
and
math
c
modules.

inline_content.Text: In Python 3.5 and higher, there is an

title:
z = cmath.rect(*cmath.polar(1+1j))

z
# Out: (1.0000000000000002+1.0000000000000002j)

cmath.isclose(z, 1+1j)
# True

content_resolved.code:
z = cmath.rect(*cmath.polar(1+1j))

z
# Out: (1.0000000000000002+1.0000000000000002j)

cmath.isclose(z, 1+1j)
# True
